Headline.Para: Flying high as Changi takes a turn for future

LeadPara.Para: The next 10 years will be tougher for Changi and it needs to have airlines and travellers on its side
Changi has become the first to win "best airport" title for six straight years in an annual ranking by London-based Skytrax.

TailParas.Para: The 2018 results were announced last Wednesday, following a poll of more than 13 million travellers of over 100 nationalities. Even sceptics of such rankings have to admit it is quite an achievement.
Given recent developments, though, one has to wonder if the winning streak is sustainable.
Over the last few weeks, Changi seems to be rubbing airlines and travellers the wrong way.
Higher airport fees and charges will soon be levied and airlines, in particular, have been unsettled by new rules to punish those who habitually arrive early or late.

Netizens have taken to social media to express their unhappiness over the impending fee hikes, while airlines have found a strong supporter in the International Air Transport Association (Iata) - a global airline body.

Travellers at Changi Airport's Terminal 1. The writer says that as Changi celebrates its sixth Skytrax win of the "best airport" title, it must do more to engage its key stakeholders if it wants to bring home the gold for many more years to come. PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI
While the title of world's best airport has turned some of the bricks to bouquets, it is clear the angst has not died down.
Trouble for Changi started on Feb 28 when travellers and airlines were told that they would have to pay more from July 1.
Departure fees that travellers pay when flying out of Changi Airport will increase by $13.30 to $47.30, and hit $62.30 by April 1, 2024.

For airlines, aircraft landing, parking and aerobridge fees will go up by 1 per cent on July 1. The charges will increase again by 1 per cent annually from April 1 next year, with the last hike on April 1, 2024.
The Government says the increases are necessary to help fund a major airport expansion project that would include building a third runway and mega passenger facility, Terminal 5.

With the Changi East development - as the project is referred to - expected to cost tens of billions of dollars, the higher fees and charges to be collected from travellers and airlines will cover just a small portion of the total bill, the authorities have said repeatedly.
They point to other airports in Hong Kong, Taipei and Dubai, for example, that have also introduced new fees to fund expansion projects.

But with T5 due to open only around 2030, although all three runways will be up and running in the early 2020s, airport users here are also asking why they have to pay for something they may not even end up using.
The official response: The higher charges now are aimed at avoiding large spikes later on.
Public and industry disquiet had yet to settle when another whammy hit airlines last week.
This time, they were told that, with Changi Airport getting busier, there is a need to ensure optimal use of resources like landing slots and aircraft gates.

So with effect from a date not yet announced, airlines whose planes keep arriving early or late without a good reason, such as bad weather, will risk losing their landing slots and be fined up to $100,000.
In principle, this makes perfect sense because every flight that does not come on time causes a potential disruption, including delays for other airlines and passengers.

The concern for airlines, though, is that delays are not always their fault - some stem from the airports they take off from - but having to prove their case to the Singapore authorities could be cumbersome.
After flying high for almost four decades, Changi Airport is steering into unfamiliar skies.
Not since the 1970s has Singapore embarked on such a major airport expansion, which will almost double the airport's existing size.

For the first time, there are also serious concerns - as traffic continues to grow - of a capacity crunch on the ground and in the air that could impact service levels in the last few years before T5 opens around 2030.
The next 10 years are likely to be tougher for Changi than the last 37 that it has been operational. Now, more than ever, the airport needs its airlines and travellers on its side.

Travellers should be easier to handle. While the departure fee will increase, it will be collected by airlines as part of the airfare and for many travellers, the total matters more than the different components it comprises of.
With competition between airlines expected to stay intense, fares are likely to remain attractive even as Government fees increase.
With airlines, Changi has to tread more carefully.
The chief of Australian low-cost carrier Jetstar, Mr Gareth Evans, has already said that the airline may have to shift flights around because of the higher airport charges that will impact demand.
Whether the airline will reduce services to Singapore remains to be seen but the fact that Mr Evans even made the remarks should cause Changi some concern.
Of course, it is not so easy to cut flights, especially for point-to-point traffic where traveller demand is strong. You cannot tell a businessman who has work in Singapore to fly elsewhere.
Leisure and transit traffic, though, is easier to manipulate and the demand could shift out of Singapore to other airports and destinations. This could pose a bigger risk for Changi Airport.
Discussions with airlines suggest, anecdotally, that Changi has become less consultative. It is often a case of "do first and explain later".
When news broke of the penalties to be imposed on airlines that do not watch their clocks, it surprised many in the industry, including Iata - which said it was not aware of the plans.
Iata Asia-Pacific spokesman Albert Tjoeng, who is based in Singapore, said the association looks forward to engaging the Government "in meaningful consultations to understand better the new scheme".

In fact, given that the number of incidents of airlines repeatedly and deliberately not keeping to their landing slot times is low - according to the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore - one could argue that there is no need for pecuniary measures at this stage.
There must be a better way of working with the industry to make sure everyone understands the need to keep to given times as the airport becomes busier in the coming years.
As Changi Airport celebrates its sixth Skytrax win, it must do more to engage its key stakeholders if it wants to bring home the gold for many more years to come.
